formats.name: micro_manifesto
formats.instruction: Write a bold, one-sentence manifesto for how people should approach life or a topic. Maximum punch, minimal length.

formats.name: split_screen
formats.instruction: Present two contrasting perspectives side-by-side: write two distinct takes on the same issue, separated by a clear visual break. Each side should be concise but specific.

formats.name: pattern_interrupt
formats.instruction: Describe an odd pattern or recurring behavior you see in the world, then explain why it surprises or bothers you. Use an evocative metaphor or analogy.

formats.name: fictional_feedback
formats.instruction: Pretend you’re giving feedback to a famous historical figure (or fictional character) about their choices. Write as if you’re critiquing their strategy or worldview. Lean into humor or absurdity.

formats.name: the_deep_cut
formats.instruction: Reveal a little-known detail or hidden perspective about your topic. Dive deep into its origins or mechanics, sharing something most readers wouldn't guess. Use layered explanations.

formats.name: dream_sequence
formats.instruction: Imagine a surreal or impossible scenario related to your topic. Narrate it vividly as if it were a dream, then connect it back to real-world insights or questions.

formats.name: snake_case_shorts
formats.instruction: Convey your entire idea in a string of punchy snake_case phrases, each adding nuance or twist. No full sentences. Use 5-12 phrases.

formats.name: timeline_tussle
formats.instruction: Draft a brief timeline of a topic’s evolution, then speculate on what comes next and why. Use dates, short blurbs, and a prediction at the end.

formats.name: reverse_engineering
formats.instruction: Start with the bizarre or surprising result, then work backwards to reconstruct the sequence that led there. Use each paragraph to ‘rewind’ a step.

title_styles: Use a poetic visual metaphor as a title. Examples: 'When opinions ripple like pond water', 'Ideas with hidden trapdoors'
Write a provocative, question-based title. Examples: 'What makes a pattern weird?', 'Who actually benefits from simplicity?'
Start your title with 'Dear...' and address an idea or topic as if it’s a person. Examples: 'Dear Distraction: you never change', 'Dear Collaboration: teach us your secrets'
Write a title that uses future tense to hint at big predictions. Examples: 'Why your workspace will look unrecognizable in five years', 'Tomorrow’s mistakes are today’s habits'
Craft a title entirely in snake_case, with no spaces. Example: 'deeper_than_you_think', 'pattern_interrupts_everywhere'
structure_variants: Begin and end with a striking visual image or sensory description.
Organize your post as a series of hypothetical 'what if' questions and answers.
Interleave short narrative snapshots with analytical commentary.
Write as a dialogue between unexpected characters (e.g., a robot and a philosopher).
Use a single timeline running vertically, with each segment marked by a date or event.
